name: Newton's Laws of Motion
latex: \begin{aligned} \mathbf{F} &= m\mathbf{a} \\ \mathbf{F}_{12} &= -\mathbf{F}_{21} \\ \text{An object at rest stays at rest} \end{aligned}
explanation: Isaac Newton's three laws (1687) form the foundation of classical mechanics. First Law: Objects maintain constant velocity unless acted upon by a force. Second Law: F = ma (force equals mass times acceleration). Third Law: For every action, there's an equal and opposite reaction. These laws describe motion from falling apples to orbiting planets and enabled the Industrial Revolution and space exploration.

examples.problem: A 10 kg object accelerates at 5 m/s². What force is applied?
When you push a wall with 100 N of force, what happens?
examples.solution: The wall pushes back with 100 N (Newton's Third Law)
steps: Your force on wall: 100 N forward
Wall's force on you: 100 N backward
These forces are equal and opposite

proof: Newton synthesized Galileo's work on falling bodies and Kepler's planetary laws. The laws are empirical (based on observation) and form the axiomatic foundation of classical mechanics.
